message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest ankylosing spondylitis, and among the options, tenderness at the Achilles tendon insertion site is a common symptom of this condition. Paresthesia over the anterolateral part of the thigh is a symptom of meralgia paresthetica, which is not associated with ankylosing spondylitis. Nail pitting and separation of the nail from the nailbed are seen in psoriasis, while ulnar deviation of the fingers bilaterally is seen in rheumatoid arthritis, neither of which are associated with ankylosing spondylitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest ankylosing spondylitis, which can also affect the Achilles tendon insertion site. Paresthesia over the anterolateral part of the thigh is seen in meralgia paresthetica. Nail pitting and separation of the nail from the nailbed is seen in psoriasis. Ulnar deviation of the fingers bilaterally is seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including lower back pain, morning stiffness that improves with activity, decreased chest expansion, and elevated inflammatory markers, suggest ankylosing spondylitis. The tenderness over the sacroiliac joints and limited range of motion further supports this diagnosis. Tenderness at the Achilles tendon insertion site is a common finding in ankylosing spondylitis, due to inflammation of the entheses. Paresthesia over the anterolateral part of the thigh is a symptom of meralgia paresthetica, which is not related to ankylosing spondylitis. Nail pitting and separation of the nail from the nailbed are associated with psoriasis. Ulnar deviation of the fingers bilaterally is a physical finding that may be seen in rheumatoid arthritis, but is not specific to ankylosing spondylitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the x-ray findings suggest ankylosing spondylitis, a type of arthritis that affects the spine and the sacroiliac joints. Tenderness at the Achilles tendon insertion site is a common finding in patients with ankylosing spondylitis. Paresthesia over the anterolateral part of the thigh is associated with meralgia paresthetica, which is caused by compression of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve. Nail pitting and separation of the nail from the nailbed are seen in psoriasis. Ulnar deviation of the fingers bilaterally is a classic finding in rheumatoid arthritis.

Tenderness at the Achilles tendon insertion site is a common finding in ankylosing spondylitis. Paresthesia over the anterolateral part of the thigh is seen in meralgia paresthetica, which is caused by compression of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve. Nail pitting and separation of the nail from the nail bed are seen in psoriasis. Ulnar deviation of the fingers is seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including back pain and shortness of breath, suggest ankylosing spondylitis, and the x-ray findings support this diagnosis. Tenderness at the Achilles tendon insertion site is a common finding in patients with ankylosing spondylitis, while paresthesia over the anterolateral part of the thigh is associated with meralgia paresthetica. Nail pitting and separation of the nail from the nailbed are associated with psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis, while ulnar deviation of the fingers is seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest ankylosing spondylitis, which commonly presents with sacroiliitis, decreased spinal mobility, and decreased chest expansion. Tenderness at the Achilles tendon insertion site is also a common finding in ankylosing spondylitis, known as enthesitis. Paresthesia over the anterolateral part of the thigh and ulnar deviation of the fingers are not associated with ankylosing spondylitis. Nail pitting and separation of the nail from the nailbed are associated with psoriatic arthritis.

Paresthesia over the anterolateral part of the thigh is associated with meralgia paresthetica, nail pitting and separation of the nail from the nailbed is associated with psoriasis, and ulnar deviation of the fingers bilaterally is associated with rheumatoid arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The back pain, shortness of breath, and leukocytosis suggest an inflammatory process, and the tenderness over the sacroiliac joints and limited range of motion suggest ankylosing spondylitis. Tenderness at the Achilles tendon insertion site is a common finding in ankylosing spondylitis, also known as enthesitis. Paresthesia over the anterolateral part of the thigh is a symptom of meralgia paresthetica, which is unrelated to ankylosing spondylitis. Nail pitting and separation of the nail from the nailbed are associated with psoriasis, and ulnar deviation of the fingers bilaterally is a sign of rheumatoid arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s back pain is worse in the morning and improves with exercise, which suggests Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS). The tenderness over the sacroiliac joints and erosion and sclerosis of the sacroiliac joints on spine x-ray is consistent with AS. Examination of the Achilles tendon is commonly used in the diagnosis of AS, as patients with AS may show tenderness at the site of insertion of the Achilles tendon, so the correct answer is (C). Nail pitting and separation of the nail from the nailbed is a common finding in psoriasis, not AS. Paresthesia over the anterolateral part of the thigh is indicative of meralgia paresthetica, a condition that occurs due to compression of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve in the thigh. Ulnar deviation of the fingers bilaterally is seen in Rheumatoid Arthritis.
